com:
>A development and test team comprising the German Armed Forces, Airbus, the German Aerospace Center, Steinbeis Flugzeug- und Leichtbau GmbH (SFL) and Gerardts GmbH has launched an Airbus Do DT25 drone from a flying A400M. According to an Airbus statement, this was the world's first successful launch and operation of a remote carrier from an A400M.

>The drone was scaffolded out and into the A400M as a flight test demonstrator to showcase the Remote Carrier as it is designed to be a capability carrier for the Future Combat Air System (FCAS). According to Airbus, the Remote Carrier is intended to increase the effectiveness and range of unmanned systems.

>Regarding the importance and the process, Airbus writes: "Remote carriers will be an important component of FCAS. They will fly in close cooperation with manned aircraft and support pilots in their tasks and missions. Military transport aircraft such as the A400M play an important role in this: as a mother ship, they bring the remote carriers as close as possible to their area of operation and then drop off up to 50 small or up to 12 heavy remote carriers. These then fly in tandem with manned aircraft, operating with a high degree of automation but always under the control of a pilot."

>Using new working methods, including rapid prototyping and a joint flight test approach, the multidisciplinary team developed, integrated and prepared the A400M UAV launcher for flight testing in a very short time, Airbus said. The German Federal Office of Bundeswehr Equipment, Information Technology and In-Service Support supported this flexible industrial structure and new ways of working, it added.

>>56381157
Depends on the type of fusion fuel. If it's conventional fusion using hydrogen isotopes - then most of the energy will be released in the form of neutrons which don't carry charge. These require heat conversion to generate electricity.

If you use He3 (which is very rare, so a bit unviable at the moment), the fusion products are electrically charged, so you can induce a current in a electromagnetic field. Essentially, you skip the heat generation --> turbine phase and directly generate electricity by induction.

com:

Guess no new cover edition.

Resource on what these spec terminology mean
https://www.nite-walker.com/post/2019/11/21/specs-for-dummies-101
https://apollogearco.com/blogs/news/night-vision-specs-explained
https://gloomgroup.com/blogs/night-vision-info/night-vision-specifications-understanding-what-they-mean

You shouldn't be chasing for spec values but they do exist and if you wanted to know what "better spec" values are there's a way to know which unit is desirable over another.
Most retailers won't post this info as they build NVDs to order, first come first serve, and depending on their grading scale of high, mid, low tier it may differ from retailers. If a retailer offer a “ready to ship” fully built units they will list the spec values. Hand select is an option from retailers that will try to match to your spec requirements.

Some reputable retailers:
https://www.jrhenterprises.com/
https://nvisionoptics.com/
https://www.customnightvision.com/
https://gooningear.com/
https://apollogearco.com
https://blackphasetactical.com/
https://steeleindustries.com/

SNR: signal to noise ratio, the amount of signal the tube can make compared to the noise
EBI: equivalent background information, how much false image appears in the screen through which the actual image has to show, sort of a noise floor of sorts
Halo: How big the circle of bloom is around lights
Photocathode Sensitivity: How sensitive the photocathode is
LP Resolution: Line pair res of the center of the image as measure against a standardized chart

If one spec is shit it negates the rest, if you have a halo of 2.0 it kinda fucks on an EBI of 0.20 if you want to do any kind of shooting and it's all a balance game

The numbers to meet or beat are
EBI under 1, preferably under 0.6 being great, 0.1 is gucci
Halo under 1, anything under 0.7 is awesome
SNR, over 25 anything over 30 is gucci
Photocathode, 1900+ is pretty great, 2500+ is stellar
Resolution of 64+ is good, 72+ is gucci

com:
Hello. About a day ago I saw people talking about some "unusual" weapons they saw being used in Ukraine, in that case an F2000. He seemed to think that those weapons were somehow new, when in reality they're been present almost since the beginning of the war.

I don't fault him for thinking that but as a (semi) professional militaria dork I wanted to give you all a rundown on some of the weird and uncommon small arms I've seen in Ukraine, and where exactly they came from. Feel free to make a request if you'd like some specific information.

For our first example we have a PKT that was harvested from a knocked-out Russian tank and converted for infantry use. These got a decent amount of press coverage due to their unusual appearance, but I haven't seen them in use since about April or May. The facility where they were produced was eventually discovered and knocked out, and by now superior options are widely available.

name: Anonymous
com: what do you think is the best generation of g23?

last_replies.name: Resident Wumbologist
last_replies.com:
>>56380459
I have a 3rd gen from 2001 that's been fired a lot and it's still fine. Theoretically the newer 4th and 5th gens are better since they have a much better supported chamber (less gap at the bottom for the feed ramp) which provides a better safety margin although that's mostly an issue if you're reloading.
4th and 5th gen also have features like swappable magazine release orientation, grip panels, RMR cuts, things like that. Their finish doesn't seem to be as strong though, where iv;e seen chipping and fading on practically new guns but the slide coating on my 23 and 2nd gen 17 from 1990 are still mostly intact.

Tentatively I'd go with a 3rd gen because that's what I have and know, but if I had the option I wouldn't be against giving the 5th gen a chance. Really the biggest advantage of 3rd gens is cost because people are spooked by the unsupported chamber and used 3rd gen 40s are cheap as fuck.
Whichever one you get also get conversion barrels for 9mm and 357 Sig because there's no reason not to.

com: Wtf is this part of the slide called? I bought a brownells slide for my Glock 26 and I was having feeding issues, that little feed thing would scrape the next round when it would feed and would sometimes smash into the round in the mag, causing a stoppage, I compared it to my old standard slide and the bar thing on the brownells slide was just a hair taller than the standard slide, should I just buy from Glock from now on? How tf does this even happen

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56381328
It's called grippi dippy bullet puller hookey dookey thingie.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56381328
That rail strips the next cartridge out of the magazine when cycling. It has to rest along the next round when the slide is forward. When the slide moves rearward the next round pops up when it clears the rail. The rail will contact the case head and push the round into the chamber when the slide moves forward. When everything comes together to lock up, the case head will slip up and behind the extractor positioning the primer in front of the primer pin hole. Sounds like the rail is doing it's job, but something else is causing the stoppage. I doubt the rail sticks down far enough to catch on the magazine.

> pictures of the stoppage would be helpful

When does the stoppage occur? When the slide moves rearward or forward? Have you tried other magazines? Have you tried FMJ, JFP, and HP ammo? Is the ammo jamming on the magazine or feed ramp?

I had a magazine that would almost never lock the slide back. Something was off with the follower and it would always ride the right side of the magazine, and would slip right passed the slide lock on the last round.

>>56380741
Theoretically you would need to take it to an FFL and have them serialize it before it is legally considered "a gun", then finish the construction. If you are a registered manufacturer (which requires intent to manufacture for sale), you can engrave your own serial numbers.
Washington has similar laws on the books but with a hilariously broad definition of what constitutes a "gun" (literally a block of untouched aluminum that you intend to turn into a gun at some point, or that a cop thinks looks like a gun part, counts), and also makes it illegal to remove the serial number once it's on the "part" so it's effectively illegal to machine. They require similar catch-22 serialization on SBRs and explicitly limit machine guns to no more than 299 RPM. None of this has been challenged in court yet, we're working on it.

Back when the Olympic Games weren't fucking gay, Olympic Pistol Duels were a thing, where you'd use a percussion cap (but no powder) and a wax roundball, and the contestants would wear protective gear.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KWlAIcwxxD0
Do the paces, turn, and whoever hits first wins.

You could probably get up to this yourself, and even do so safely, BUT, I would say that you should experiment very carefully to figure out how this shit is gonna work before you try it on a whim and someone loses a tooth, an eye, or a testicle, that shit is tough to get forgiveness for.

sub: No, the sig m5 will not replace the m4
com:
Nothing about this makes any sense.

The m4 was chosen over the m16 because of its small size and low weight allowing it to excel in close ranges. They would just use heavier weapons the further away the enemy is.

The sig m5 along with its silencer and new scope will be the heaviest service rifle in US military history, and the larger round will mean way less fire power per soldier. This is a huge disadvantage in close ranges (where the small arms are meant for) as the more fire power usually wins.

It doesn’t even make sense as an anti body armor rifle. It’s round cannot pierce level 4 plates. If the military wants anti body armor ammunition they can just use 5.56 or 7.62 AP rounds they already have.

The only possible explanation that makes sense is they want a rifle specifically designed to only pierce sub-standard body armor and nothing better, as though they are afraid something more advanced will be captured and reverse engineered and used against their own level 4 plates, but if you would be fighting a major power like Russia or China they should be able to supply their troops with level 4 plates soon regardless.

>>56380992
What level of protection does the body armor worn by the enemy provide?
I would say any reliable intermediate round firing rifle is going to be good to go at the range you are expecting combat, with maybe 1-2 people carrying full sized round firing rifles for barrier penetration. Other considerations are dependent on what country you live in, which may will dictate what ammo ammo and spare parts you have access to. Cost is also a factor and intermediate rounds generally cost less than full-sized.
In the USA and much of the western world, the ar-15 is going to be a good option due to it's intersections of availability (which extendeds to spare parts and ammo), reliability, modularity, weight, ergonomics, price, and lethality.
As far as a "battle rifle" goes there are many options but I would say that an "ar-10" pattern rifle is probably going to be your best bet when considering the above list, though there are many other viable options.
If you are in some former eastern bloc, an ak pattern platform may suit you better for an intermediate rifle. Soviet full sized rifle rounds are rimmed which makes them a bit more difficult to pack them into a compact and detachable magazine.

I've been following Russian military blogs and Telegram channels and they seem to be consistently pissed off at the leadership for the past few weeks. Not because the war was wrong or even that they're losing. But because the Russian leadership is being too nice by giving back land as part of "goodwill gestures", refusing to use the elite forces that they totally have, and not flattening Kyiv with carpet bombing when they totally could.

You can see it on this very board. Right now that's "haha copium" material, but I'm curious if this strain of thought will actually seriously impact Russian culture post-war. Living conditions might worsen, people will notice how many of their relatives are dying, but there won't be a decisive, undeniable sign that their country went all-out and still lost crushingly. Combine that with the recurring propaganda from the Russian government that they're somehow still holding back.

It seems like a stab in the back myth in the making. How do you truly convince the Russians that they've lost? And what's more, that they lost to Ukraine not 500,000 disguised NATO mercenary commandos?

2022-12-12
(Reuters) - A federal appeals court [3-judge panel] on Monday allowed New York to restrict the carrying of firearms on private property under a new law adopted in wake of a major U.S. Supreme Court ruling that expanded gun rights.

The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals put on hold a judge's order from last month that barred officials from enforcing part of the new law making it a felony to carry a gun on private property without the property owner's express consent.

It marked the latest instance of the New York-based federal appeals court staying a ruling that had blocked large parts of the Concealed Carry Improvement Act, passed this year by the Democratic-led state legislature.

The law was enacted after the Supreme Court in June struck down the state's strict gun permitting regime and declared for the first time that the U.S. Constitution protects a person's right to carry a handgun in public for self-defense.

The new law made obtaining a firearms license more difficult as of Sept. 1 and barred firearms from a long list of "sensitive" public and private places.

Two firearms owners and two gun rights groups including Firearms Policy Coalition sued to challenge a provision that made it a felony for a licensed gun owner to possess a firearm on any private property unless the property owner allowed it with a sign or by giving express consent.

U.S. District Judge John Sinatra, an appointee of former Republican President Donald Trump in Buffalo, in a Nov. 22 decision concluded that provision violated the U.S. Constitution's Second Amendment right to "keep and bear arms."

Sinatra said the provision was unconstitutional under the Supreme Court's gun rights precedents and would "interfere with the Second Amendment rights of law-abiding citizens who seek to carry for self-defense outside of their own homes."

com:
Why are CZs so fucking gritty? Everytime I rack my CZ-75D it sounds like metal grinding itself away. I lubed the shit out of every contact surface with moving metal parts with Ballistol and it still sounded gritty and felt very unsmooth. Normally I reserve grease for AKs but I greased it and it still isn't even as smooth as its competitors like the M9/92FS and P226. Both of which I've owned and shot very well with especially the M9. It just doesn't shoot, rack, or takedown for cleaning as well as a lot of other pistols. It feels inferior. The trigger might be literally the only thing that's above average on it.

But it STILL has this slight grinding sound after greasing it even. I've owned it for two and a half years and it should be "well broken in" by now. I've put 1,000 rounds through it at least. I've thought about swapping the factory recoil spring and shitty polymer guide rod with a steel rod and higher quality spring. Maybe doing a little "cajunizing" or whatever but I don't think it'll even stack up to what I want. I'm not going to just sell it yet but I don't want to drop more money into it if its just a lost cause. My Glock even feels as good or better and I really don't like Glocks a whole lot.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56379397
>How hard is it to operate a black powder revolver and not blow my hand off?
The risk of blowing off your hand is exaggerated. Running improperly patched and sealed loads does mean that you're more likely to get a chainfire. But that mostly just ruins the gun, and the majority of injuries from those are to the eyes or fingers rather than "blowing your hand off".
More importantly, it is very, very easy to ruin a BP revolver if you don't clean and maintain it correctly. It requires some pretty fiddly takedown and reassembly to deep-clean one, and trying to ham-hand it back together can easily ruin the timing or fuck up the pawl. As with any BP weapon, you will need to clean one ASAP after firing. People that are lazy or dumb have a bad habit of putting this off, and if you get pitting corrosion on the forcing cone you have just made your gun into a $300+ paperweight.
By contrast throwing a conversion cylinder into it and getting it timed up will be relatively cheap, at which point the gun will work (and need to be maintained) like a modern revolver.
